definition: Cao Zhi (192-232), son of Cao Cao 曹操, noted poet and calligrapher
class or grade/generation/plaintiff and defendant (old)/government department (old)
surname Cao/Zhou Dynasty vassal state
to plant

sentences.english: The expressing of individual life consciousness is the source of returning to Qu Yuans potery, It.
sentences.chinese: 曹植的辭賦便可視爲此種個體生命意識的渲泄和表達。

sentences.english: Here we try to discuss some of these problems so that it will be helpful for the renovation of CAO Zhi Collection.
sentences.chinese: 對其中部分問題加以探討，有助於曹植集的重新整理。

sentences.english: Mr. Cao Zhi is a famous poet and expert int he writing of memorial to the throne.
sentences.chinese: 曹植不但是傑出的詩人，而且是寫作章表的方家。

sentences.english: Opinions in the literature, Cao Pi and Cao Zhi on the surface seems to be different.
sentences.chinese: 在文學的意見上，曹丕和曹植表面上似乎是不同的。

sentences.english: Caozhi paid great attention to the morality, and insisted on the morality even in adversity.
sentences.chinese: 曹植重視立德，即使身處逆境也能堅持不渝。

definition: Cao Pi (187-226), second son of Cao Cao 曹操, king then emperor of Cao Wei 曹魏 from 220, ruled as Emperor Wen 魏文帝, also a noted calligrapher
Wang Can (177-217), poet, generally regarded as the most brilliant of "the seven masters of Jian'an" 建安[Jian4 an1]
Sima Yi (179-251), warlord under Cao Cao and subsequently founder of the Jin dynasty

Cao Cao (155-220), famous statesman and general at the end of Han, noted poet and calligrapher, later warlord, founder and first king of Cao Wei 曹魏, father of Emperor Cao Pi 曹丕/the main villain of novel the Romance of Three Kingdoms 三國演義|三国演义
Cao Chong (196-208), son of Cao Cao 曹操[Cao2 Cao1]
Xun Yu (163-212), brilliant strategist, advisor of Cao Cao in Three Kingdoms
Sun Quan (reigned 222-252), southern warlord and king of state of Wu 吳|吴 in the Three Kingdoms period
Sima Zhao (211-265), military general and statesman of Cao Wei 曹魏[Cao2 Wei4]
Cao Pi 曹丕, emperor of Wei 220-226
Zhou Yu or Chou Yü (175-210), famous general of the southern Wu kingdom and victor of the battle of Redcliff/in Romance of the Three Kingdoms, absolutely no match for Zhuge Liang
Kong Rong (153-208), poet of the Three Kingdoms period
Zhong Yao (151-230), minister of Cao Wei 曹魏[Cao2 Wei4] and noted calligrapher, said to have developed the regular script 楷書|楷书[kai3 shu1]
Sun Ce (175-200), general and major warlord of the Later Han Dynasty
Emperor Xian of Han (181-234), the final Han emperor, set up by Dong Zhuo 董卓, reigned 189-220, forced to abdicate 220 by Cao Pi 曹丕
Yuan Shao (153-202), general during late Han, subsequently warlord
Liu Bei (161-223), warlord at the end of the Han dynasty and founder of the Han kingdom of Shu 蜀漢|蜀汉 (c. 200-263), later the Shu Han dynasty
